We love to pass judgment on other people.  I think in some ways we are here trying to bolt the barn door after we have lured out some of the horses ourselves, and now the rest have followed suit and left, too; we may have thought that all we were doing was something appropriate, like passing judgment on those who had broken community codes of behavior, but the template can be used for all kinds of things, including financial and political profit.  These kinds of books seem to me to be in some ways an outgrowth of qualities we accept if not encourage (in our court system, in investigative reporting), and we think we can manage the situation by drawing a line somewhere and getting everyone to recognize it.  Kind of like the investment arena, where we expect self-regulation and it doesn't always happen.  But I don't really expect everybody to immediately stop the great American pastime of passing judgment on one another and dig it out root and branch, but maybe in the short term we will develop an awareness that it's a habit that can grow out of control.

This is the flipside of the kind of criticism that used to be leveled when passages of books or any type of media came to represent the whole. Most people will never read either of these and only know them from what has been written and said about them. Mr. Bruni has done two things well: showed that marketers have taken control away from reporters of this pre-release image, and, two, given the clarion call that scorched-earth brutality toward politicians is leaving a barren political landscape. But it needs more than than the trumpet doesn't it? In both cases, media formerly highlighting details from books and other cultural analyses and using the details to give an emperor's yea or nay, and now, in our everyone's-a-publisher world, holding public leaders like bugs under a magnifying glass in the sun of public scrutiny, we reap what we sow. I have no solution. Neither the bastion mentality nor complete openness seems the answer. And the media genie is out of the bottle and isn't going back in.

Isn't some of it that everything is a business now, everything is about money? Those peddling this stuff can say, well, that's what the public wants to know, that's what sells books/magazines/newspapers, etc etc etc.

I'm sick of what "the public" wants. Quit giving it to them or we will have no decent civic life left.

Yet based on the view back in time we have also had some very good public officials and a lot more not so very good ones. The recent case of a former President who had numerous extramarital affairs while in office all covered up by the mainstream media because that was how things were done then comes to mind. If you claim to be the party of "No Personal Limits" and you wish to win the votes of those that disagree with that Philosophy it's in your best interest for the personal lives of your politicians to be kept as private as possible. Alas with the coming of the Internet that is no longer possible anyone can and does "Out" the notable as Gary Hart, John Edwards, W.J. Clinton, Al Gore, and too many Governors, Senators, Congressman, and Mayors to list here have discovered.
The theory is advanced here that the elimination of these Hypocrites and Oath-breakers from Public Office is a Bad Thing. Well, based on the results of the last 60 years having them in Public Office can be viewed as a Bad Thing taking where we are today as proof. Today for better or worse the Political Class in the U.S. must "walk the walk" as well as "talk the talk" or tell the Public up front what kind of a person they are. If they don't someone will "Out" them. In my opinion that is an improvement that will make things better.

It's too bad someone who received a Pulitzer Prize for his newspaper reporting on a young inner city man who goes on to an Ivy League university (later a book titled "A Hope in the Unseen", 1999) has now fallen into the gutter with all the other journalistic hacks.

It wasn't Jersey Shore, for God's sake! She just wanted to showcase her beloved state of Alaska. She deserves her privacy as much as the next person.

Bravo, Mr. Bruni.  When an anything goes kind of commentary or investigative journalism prevails we have the result of a TMZ kind of country where only Paris Hiltonesque celebrities will subject themselves to the kind of parasitic invasion as Mr. Siskand demonstrated.  Salacious gossip and wild speculation does nothing to help us choose a competent candidate, and it hinders a true leader from emerging, which we so desperately require.  Mr. Siskand is an outlier, but how much more vicious rhetoric can we read on even more respectable websites?  We ought to be holding journalists to higher standards, and maybe our candidates would follow.

If there's a shrewd entrepeneur lurking here, he or she can make a fortune by offering smelling salts to Mr. Bruni and all his sensitive admirers.

Christine O'Donnell not only proclaimed to the world her devotion to abstinence, she swore she was not a witch. All this while running for public office.

Sarah Palin used (and continues to use) her family--and especially her handicapped child--as props in her interminable greed-driven reality show.

The President's financial team exploited his naivete so they could continue to do the slimy bidding of the bankers and money managers who have crippled the American economy. Crippled it for years to come.

But Mr. Bruni and his cheerleaders are fainting at the nasty anecdotes about this crew of cartoon characters.

Try another universe--one in which mortgage holders don't throw 102-year-old widows out of their homes, and NYC policemen don't pepper spray caged civilians, and US troops don't continue to come home dead or shattered (or gay active-duty soldiers aren't booed by savage Republicans in front of mute Presidential wanna-bes),

You'll like that universe; you're obviously too delicate for this one.

"But the federal review found that the state had written up teachers for pronouncing 'the' as 'da,' 'another' as 'anuder' and 'lives here' as 'leeves here.'"

"But" ????? These are out-and-out pronunciation errors, so why shouldn't the teachers who speak this way be coached on correct pronunciation? Just as public school teachers everywhere are coached on lesson plans, class discipline, and other things?

Arizona is a state that has shown indications of xenophobia. But it doesn't follow that all actions it takes that affect non-native English speakers more than others are necessarily evil.

So Spanish-based accents are so bad that speakers can't be around children learning English (because "eeekk... contamination!"), but there's no mention of the different Southern, Bostonian, New York/Long Island, upper Midwestern, Down East, or immigrant British, Australian or New Zealand accents that other teachers must bring into the classroom. Interesting double standard.

"If only they'd all grow up to speak English as good as Ms. Aguayo."

Tut, tut, ESL teacher Harper (#74), that "good" ain't good at all. I hope your students don't speak English as poorly as you.

My only comment on using understandable English is that there are instances where not understanding what someone is telling you can be dangerous. Such as your pharmacist. One of the registered pharmacists where I pick up my prescriptions has such a heavy accent (SW Asia)that I frequently have to ask someone else to translate.
I am not a person unacquainted with accents either. I was born in the east, raised in the midwest, lived in Mexico and currently live in Texas. I speak Spanish well enough that I am frequently asked where I am from by native speakers. However, I do believe that an effort should be made by anyone who lives here to work on their pronunciation. It shows consideration to everyone else.

@Commenter 189:

Read the post by Commenter 191 and then come back and insist - with a straight face - that there is no racist element to the topic at hand.

I have a strong German accent that I've been unable to shed, even though my siblings had little trouble doing so. Growing up in the Northeast, I later moved to southeastern Michigan, where, according to H.L. Mencken's "The American Language," the best American English is (or used to be) spoken. My stepson, speaking this sort of English in a highly educated professional level in New York where he now lives and practices law, nevertheless periodically gets teased about his supposed midwestern accent. By New Yorkers and New Jerseyans, no less! Spanish is spoken with radically different accents and dialects in various parts of the world. Just ask a Mexican about the Spanish that is spoken in Cuba and Puerto Rico (where I've also lived), and vice-versa. Next to none of the kids in Arizona whose first language is Spanish will ever speak English with a native American accent, whatever that may be, regardless of what accent their teacher has. Perhaps, for them, having a teacher who is a native Mexican who made it in the United States will serve to motivate them to do the same.
While I feel a bit guilty about it, these days I wouldn't be caught dead staying overnight in Arizona. Ugly Ugly Ugly.
I'm sick of people who can't speak English properly expecting and demanding to have all the rights of those in an English speaking country.  Let's make English our official language, legally.
